questions.text: Which second-generation antipsychotic is FDA-approved for use in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) to manage irritability?
questions.solution:
SECOND-GENERATION ANTIPSYCHOTICS (SGAS):

  • SGAs, also known as atypical antipsychotics, have largely replaced first-generation antipsychotics (FGAs).
  • They are called "atypical" due to their broader spectrum of action and lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).

Key Differences Between SGAs and FGAs:

  • SGAs have a lower risk of EPS but can cause significant weight gain and increased risk of diabetes.
  • FDA requires monitoring for metabolic side effects in patients using SGAs.

Mechanism of Action:

  • SGAs block D2 dopamine receptors, but they also have a higher affinity for serotonin receptors (e.g., 5-HT2A), which contributes to their unique side effect profiles.

Therapeutic Uses:

  • SGAs are approved for the treatment of schizophrenia, acute mania, and bipolar disorder.
  • Some are also approved as adjunctive therapy in major depressive disorder (MDD), PTSD, and anxiety disorders.
  • Effective for managing aggression and violence in certain psychiatric conditions.

Adverse Effects:

  • Common adverse effects include weight gain, diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and sedation.
  • Monitoring of weight, blood pressure, and glucose is recommended during SGA treatment.

Mood Disorder Indications:

  • Some SGAs are FDA-approved for bipolar disorder, including acute mania and maintenance.
  • Olanzapine (with fluoxetine) is approved for treatment-resistant depression.
  • Quetiapine and aripiprazole are approved as adjuncts for MDD.

Option A is incorrect because quetiapine is not FDA-approved for treating irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

Option B is incorrect because while aripiprazole is used off-label for various behavioural conditions, risperidone is the FDA-approved drug for irritability in ASD.

Option C is correct because risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder in children and adolescents.

Option D is incorrect because ziprasidone is not FDA-approved for the treatment of irritability in children with ASD.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

First-Line Treatments:

  • SGAs are generally considered first-line treatments for schizophrenia (except for clozapine, which is used for treatment-resistant cases).
  • SGAs are also first-line treatments for acute mania in bipolar disorder.

Off-Label Uses:

SGAs are used off-label for conditions like autism spectrum disorder (ASD), Tourette’s disorder, Huntington's disease, aggression in children, and psychosis due to head trauma

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is most commonly associated with Risperidone?
questions.solution:
RISPERIDONE

  • Pharmacology:
    • Benzisoxazole compound, metabolized in the liver to the active metabolite, 9-hydroxy risperidone.
    • Peak plasma levels: 1 hour for the parent compound, 3 hours for the metabolite.
    • Antagonizes serotonin (5-HT2A), dopamine (D2), α1-adrenergic, α2-adrenergic, and histamine (H1) receptors.
    • Low affinity for α-adrenergic and muscarinic receptors.
    • Half-life of risperidone and 9-hydroxy risperidone: 20 hours, suitable for once-daily dosing.
  • Side Effects:
    • EPS, weight gain, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, erectile dysfunction, and hyperprolactinemia (increased prolactin).
    • Most common reasons for discontinuation: dizziness, somnolence, and nausea.
    • Weight gain is more common in children.
    • Available as oral disintegrating tablets (Risperdal M-Tab) and depot injection (Risperdal Consta).
  • Drug Interactions:
    • CYP2D6 inhibitors (e.g., paroxetine, fluoxetine) may block the formation of the active metabolite.
    • Combined use with SSRIs may lead to elevated prolactin levels.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: One of the notable side effects of Risperidone is a marked increase in prolactin levels, which can lead to side effects like galactorrhea (milk production) and breast enlargement. Weight gain is also common, but prolactin elevation is more directly linked to Risperidone.

questions.text: What is the FDA boxed warning for Olanzapine's extended-release injectable form?
questions.solution:
The extended-release injectable form of Olanzapine (RelprevV) carries a boxed warning for Post-injection Delirium Sedation Syndrome (PDSS), which can lead to severe sedation, including coma. Patients must be observed for 3 hours after each injection.

OLANZAPINE

  • Indications:
    • Treatment of schizophrenia.
    • Acute and maintenance treatment of manic or mixed episodes in bipolar I disorder (monotherapy or adjunctive with lithium/valproate).
    • Used in combination with fluoxetine for treatment-resistant depression.
  • Pharmacology:
    • Antagonizes dopamine (D1, D2, D4), serotonin (5-HT2A, 5-HT1A), histamine (H1), and muscarinic (M1–M5) receptors.
  • Side Effects:
    • Significant weight gain (more than other atypicals), somnolence, dry mouth, dizziness, constipation, increased appetite.
    • Dose-related EPS risk.
    • Boxed warning for post-injection delirium sedation syndrome (PDSS) with long-acting IM injection.
    • Increased risk of stroke in elderly dementia patients.
  • Drug Interactions:
    • Increases serum levels when used with fluvoxamine or cimetidine.
    • Decreases serum levels with carbamazepine or phenytoin.
    • Alcohol increases absorption, leading to enhanced sedation.

Option A, C and D are incorrect .

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The extended-release injectable form of Olanzapine (Relprevv) carries a boxed warning for Post-injection Delirium Sedation Syndrome (PDSS), which can lead to severe sedation, including coma. Patients must be observed for 3 hours after each injection.

questions.text: Which receptor does clozapine primarily antagonize?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is primarily an antagonist at the 5-HT2A serotonin receptor. It also antagonizes dopamine (D1, D3, D4) and α-adrenergic receptors. Its lower affinity for D2 receptors is one reason why clozapine has a lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) compared to other antipsychotics.

CLOZAPINE

Indications:

  • Most effective for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
  • Benefits for severe tardive dyskinesia (suppresses symptoms, but they return if discontinued).
  • Used in psychotic patients intolerant of EPS from other agents.
  • Also used for treatment-resistant mania, severe psychotic depression, idiopathic Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, and suicidal schizophrenia patients.
  • Helpful in disorders like autism, OCD, and pediatric pervasive developmental disorder.

Pharmacology:

  • Antagonist of 5-HT2A, D1, D3, D4, α1 receptors.
  • Low D2 receptor antagonism (only 40-50% occupancy vs. 80% for haloperidol), likely reduces EPS.

Drug Interactions:

  • Avoid with drugs causing agranulocytosis or bone marrow suppression (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, captopril).
  • Lithium can increase seizure risk and cause confusion/movement disorders.
  • Clomipramine can increase seizure risk and elevate clozapine levels.
  • SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, paroxetine) can raise clozapine serum levels.

Side Effects:

  • Common: Sedation, dizziness, syncope, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, weight gain, constipation, anticholinergic effects, muscle weakness.
  • Hypersalivation (sialorrhea) is common, especially at night; manageable with towel over pillow.
  • Seizure risk: ~4% at doses >600 mg/day.
  • Hematologic issues: Leukopenia, granulocytopenia, agranulocytosis, fever in ~1% of patients.
  • Contraindicated with WBC <3,500 cells/mm³, previous bone marrow disorders, or history of agranulocytosis.

Monitoring:

  • Weekly WBC counts during the first 6 months, then every 2 weeks if stable.
  • Discontinue clozapine if WBC <3,000 cells/mm³ or granulocyte count <1,500/mm³.
  • Myocarditis or cardiomyopathy: Evaluate if patient presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, or tachypnea.

Key Contraindications:

  • WBC <3,500/mm³, previous bone marrow disorder, history of agranulocytosis.
  • Other bone marrow-suppressive drugs like carbamazepine should not be used concurrently.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Clozapine is primarily an antagonist at the 5-HT2A serotonin receptor. It also antagonizes dopamine (D1, D3, D4) and α-adrenergic receptors. Its lower affinity for D2 receptors is one reason why clozapine has a lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) compared to other antipsychotics.

choices.text: Increased risk of orthostasis, parkinsonism, and worsened cognition

questions.text: Which of the following is a potential risk when using First generation Antipsychotics in elderly patients with dementia?
questions.solution:
In elderly patients, especially those with dementia, DRAs/ FGAs (e.g., haloperidol) are associated with side effects like orthostasis (low blood pressure upon standing), parkinsonism, and cognitive decline. These effects can be especially problematic in this population.

DOPAMINE RECEPTOR ANTAGONISTS (DRAS):

  • DRAs were the first effective drugs for treating schizophrenia and psychotic illnesses, introduced in the 1950s with chlorpromazine (Thorazine).
  • Other DRAs include phenothiazines, butyrophenones, thioxanthenes, dibenzoxazepines, dihydroindoles, and diphenylbutylpiperidines.
  • These drugs have been largely replaced by second-generation antipsychotics (SDAs) due to their lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects (EPS), but DRAs are still used because they have lower risks of metabolic side effects (weight gain, diabetes, lipid issues).

Mechanism of Action:

  • DRAs block dopamine D2 receptors (about 72% occupancy is required for therapeutic effect).
  • These drugs also block noradrenergic, cholinergic, and histaminergic receptors, which vary among different DRAs.
  • Potency of DRAs determines the required dose:
    • Low-potency DRAs (e.g., chlorpromazine) cause more sedation and weight gain.
    • High-potency DRAs (e.g., haloperidol) cause more extrapyramidal side effects (EPS).

Side Effects:

  • Neurologic side effects are most common with DRAs.
  • Low-potency drugs tend to cause more non-neurologic side effects (e.g., sedation, weight gain).
  • High-potency drugs are more likely to cause EPS.
  • Other side effects include:
    • Sedation, tachycardia, hypotension.
    • Anticholinergic effects (e.g., dry mouth, blurred vision).
    • Weight gain and metabolic issues with low-potency agents.
    • Severe adverse effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), seizures, and agranulocytosis.

Specific Drug Examples:

  • Chlorpromazine: A low-potency drug with a higher likelihood of sedation and weight gain.
  • Haloperidol: A high-potency drug with a higher risk of EPS but effective in managing acute psychosis.
  • Pimozide: Another drug used for Tourette's disorder.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In elderly patients, especially those with dementia, DRAs/ FGAs (e.g., haloperidol) are associated with side effects like orthostasis (low blood pressure upon standing), parkinsonism, and cognitive decline. These effects can be especially problematic in this population.

questions.text: In which condition would you most likely observe "rabbit syndrome," a tremor affecting the lips and perioral muscles?
questions.solution:
"Rabbit syndrome" refers to a tremor affecting the lips and perioral muscles, and it is most commonly seen in patients with neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism. It is characterized by rhythmic movements of the lips, which can occur after prolonged use of antipsychotic medications.

MEDICATION-INDUCED MOVEMENT DISORDERS

  • Overview: Medication-induced movement disorders are commonly associated with psychotropic drugs, especially antipsychotics. These disorders involve abnormal motor activity, which may be challenging to distinguish from underlying psychiatric symptoms.

Neuroleptic (Antipsychotic)-Induced Movement Disorders

  • Parkinsonism: Common neuroleptic-related movement disorder, presenting with muscle stiffness, shuffling gait, and drooling. Rarely, a "pill-rolling" tremor occurs.
  • Acute Dystonia: Characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, including oculogyric crises, tongue protrusion, and laryngopharyngeal dystonias.
  • Akathisia: A state of restlessness with symptoms like pacing, jitteriness, and an inability to stay still.
  • Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS): A life-threatening condition marked by fever, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, and altered mental status.
  • Tardive Dyskinesia: Involuntary, irregular movements (especially perioral) that occur after long-term use of antipsychotics.

Neuroleptic-Induced Parkinsonism

  • Symptoms: Includes muscle rigidity, shuffling gait, stooped posture, and tremors. The tremor is often coarse and similar to essential tremor.
  • Epidemiology: More common in elderly patients and women, typically occurring 5-90 days after starting treatment with high-potency antipsychotics like haloperidol.
  • Etiology: Caused by dopamine receptor blockade in the basal ganglia, specifically the nigrostriatal pathway.
  • Treatment: Anticholinergic medications like benztropine (Cogentin), amantadine (Symmetrel), or diphenhydramine (Benadryl). Treatment may continue for weeks, especially in elderly patients.

Option D: Incorrect: Acute Dystonia

  • Symptoms: Sudden, painful muscle contractions resulting in abnormal postures such as oculogyric crises, tongue protrusion, torticollis, and laryngeal dystonias.
  • Epidemiology: More common in young men, especially those receiving high doses of high-potency antipsychotics.
  • Treatment: Intramuscular or intravenous anticholinergics (e.g., diphenhydramine) are first-line. Benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) may also be used.

Option C: Incorrect: Tardive Dyskinesia

  • Symptoms: Involuntary, irregular movements, especially of the face (e.g., tongue movements, lip smacking, facial grimacing). Can also affect limbs and trunk.
  • Epidemiology: Occurs in 10-20% of patients after long-term antipsychotic use (typically more than 6 months). Women, elderly, and those with brain damage or mood disorders are at higher risk.
  • Course and Prognosis: Remission occurs in 5-40% of cases, but it is less likely in older patients.
  • Treatment:
    • Prevention: Use of antipsychotics at the lowest effective dose.
    • Switching to atypical antipsychotics (e.g., clozapine) can reduce symptoms.
    • Valbenazine is FDA-approved for treating tardive dyskinesia.
    • In cases of severe tardive dyskinesia, switching medications or adding lithium, carbamazepine, or benzodiazepines may be beneficial.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is most likely to induce postural tremor in a patient?
questions.solution:
Lithium is one of the medications most commonly associated with postural tremors. These tremors are fine, rhythmic, and can be exacerbated by stress, anxiety, or caffeine.

Medication-Induced Postural Tremor

  • Symptoms: Rhythmic, fine tremors (8-12 Hz), usually during physical movement and aggravated by stress/anxiety.
  • Epidemiology: Seen with medications like lithium, stimulants, antidepressants, caffeine, and valproate.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduce the dose of the psychiatric drug.
    • Limit caffeine consumption.
    • Use beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) for symptomatic relief.

Other Movement Disorders

  • Nocturnal Myoclonus: Sudden jerks of leg muscles during sleep, causing frequent awakenings and unrefreshing sleep. Occurs in 40% of those over 65, often as a side effect of SSRIs.
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines, levodopa, quinine, opioids.
  • Restless Leg Syndrome: Deep, creeping sensations in the legs causing an irresistible urge to move them, often at rest.
  • Treatment: Dopamine receptor agonists (e.g., ropinirole, pramipexole), benzodiazepines, levodopa, quinine, opioids

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Lithium induced postural tremors include :Rhythmic, fine tremors (8-12 Hz), usually during physical movement and aggravated by stress/anxiety.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of vortioxetine (Trintellix)?
questions.solution:
VORTIOXETINE

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Primarily inhibits serotonin (5-HT) reuptake.
    • Acts as a 5-HT1A receptor agonist, partial agonist at 5-HT1B receptors, and antagonist at 5-HT3, 5-HT1D, and 5-HT7 receptors.
    • This combination of activities contributes to its antidepressant effects, but the exact contribution of each is not fully established.
  • Side Effects:
    • Common side effects in trials: nausea, constipation, vomiting.
    • Other potential side effects not specified in detail.
  • Special Dosing Considerations:
    • CYP2D6 poor metabolizers: Max recommended dose is 10 mg/day.
    • CYP2D6 potent inhibitors (e.g., fluoxetine, paroxetine, quinidine): Reduce dose by 50%.
    • CYP inducers (e.g., carbamazepine, rifampin): Dose adjustment is needed if used long-term (greater than 14 days).
    • Discontinuation: Can be abruptly stopped, but patients may experience transient symptoms like headache or muscle tension. Gradual tapering to 10 mg/day for 1 week before stopping is recommended for higher doses (15-20 mg/day).

Option A: Inhibition of serotonin (5-HT) reuptake: Vortioxetine primarily acts as a serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI), which increases serotonin levels in the synaptic cleft, contributing to its antidepressant effects.

Option B: Agonism of serotonin (5-HT) 1A receptors
Incorrect: While vortioxetine does act as an agonist at the 5-HT1A receptor, this is a secondary mechanism and not its primary mode of action. Its main effect is the inhibition of serotonin reuptake.

Option C: Partial agonism at serotonin (5-HT) 1B receptors

Vortioxetine also has partial agonist activity at 5-HT1B receptors, but this is not the primary action responsible for its therapeutic effects. The main action is serotonin reuptake inhibition.

Option D: Antagonism of serotonin (5-HT) 3 receptors: Vortioxetine antagonizes 5-HT3 receptors, but this action contributes to its side effect profile (such as nausea), not its primary antidepressant effect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Acts as a 5-HT1A receptor agonist, partial agonist at 5-HT1B receptors, and antagonist at 5-HT3, 5-HT1D, and 5-HT7 receptors

choices.text: Increased risk of suicidal thoughts or behaviours

questions.text: What is the main risk associated with SSRI use in children and adolescents?
questions.solution:
The FDA has issued a black box warning for SSRIs, citing an increased risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviours in children and young adults. This is particularly noted during the initial phase of treatment.

THERAPEUTIC INDICATIONS FOR SSRIs

  • Depression:
    • SSRIs are first-line treatments for depression due to safety, simplicity, and broad action.
    • SSRIs are not always superior to each other; response varies by individual, so trying different SSRIs is recommended before considering non-SSRIs.
  • Depression in Pregnancy:
    • Relapse risk in pregnant women is high if SSRIs are discontinued (68-100%).
    • SSRIs, especially fluoxetine, do not significantly increase birth defect risk (except paroxetine).
    • Paroxetine is associated with heart defects and should be avoided during pregnancy.
    • Some SSRIs may cause slight neonatal pulmonary hypertension (rare).
  • SSRIs in Elderly and Medically Ill:
    • Generally safe for elderly and those with medical conditions.
    • Potential side effects include cognitive deficits, hyponatremia, and bleeding risk.
  • SSRIs in Children/Adolescents:
    • Controversial due to potential increased suicidal thoughts.
    • Fluoxetine is most effective in children and adolescents for treating depression.
    • Use should be within comprehensive management, including therapy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Suicide Risk:

  • FDA black box warning for suicidal thoughts in children/adolescents.
  • Recent reanalysis shows SSRIs reduce suicidal behaviour in adults through symptom improvement.
  • Close monitoring is required, especially during initial treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be combined with venlafaxine due to the risk of serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Venlafaxine should not be used in combination with MAOIs due to the risk of serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition.

SNRIs

  • Overview:
    • SNRIs include venlafaxine (Effexor), desvenlafaxine (Pristiq), duloxetine (Cymbalta), and levomilnacipran (Fetzima).
    • A fifth, milnacipran (Savella), is approved for fibromyalgia but not for depression in the U.S.
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Block both serotonin (5-HT) and norepinephrine reuptake.
    • Distinguish from tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) by lower receptor affinity, leading to better tolerability.
  • Venlafaxine and Desvenlafaxine:
    • Venlafaxine: Approved for MDD, GAD, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder.
    • Desvenlafaxine (DVS): Approved for MDD
  • Common Side Effects:
    • Venlafaxine: Nausea, sexual side effects (e.g., decreased libido, delayed orgasm), headache, dizziness, insomnia.
    • DVS: Similar side effects; however, less frequent dose-related efficacy improvement above 50 mg/day.
  • Precautions:
    • Venlafaxine: May increase blood pressure (especially at high doses).
    • Discontinuation Syndrome: Withdrawal symptoms may occur if stopped abruptly, requiring a gradual taper.
    • Risk of serotonin syndrome when combined with MAOIs.
  • Drug Interactions:

Venlafaxine is metabolized by CYP2D6 and should not be combined with MAOIs due to serotonin syndrome risk.

  • It may increase the levels of certain drugs, like desipramine and risperidone.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Venlafaxine should not be used in combination with MAOIs due to the risk of serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition

questions.text: How quickly does ketamine typically provide relief from depression after administration?
questions.solution:
Ketamine can provide rapid relief from depression, often within 4 hours of a single low-dose intravenous (IV) administration. The effects can persist for weeks, though relapse is common without additional treatment.

NMDA Receptor Antagonists

  • Ketamine:
    • Primary Use: Used in specialized centers for depression treatment.
    • Mechanism: Noncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist, also inhibits dopamine transporters.
    • Effect: Provides rapid relief from depression (within 4 hours of IV administration), but the relief is often temporary, leading to relapse without additional treatment.
    • Side Effects: General anesthetic and psychotomimetic effects. At low doses, considered safe, but staff should be prepared for any respiratory or bradycardia-related issues.
  • Esketamine:
    • Approval: FDA-approved in 2019 for depression treatment.
    • Forms: Available as both an injectable form and nasal spray.
    • Mechanism: Similar to ketamine (NMDA receptor antagonist), but lacks action on sigma receptors, which reduces psychotomimetic effects.
    • Side Effects: Sedation, vision and speech difficulties, confusion, dissociation, delirium, anxiety, and increased blood pressure. Must be administered in a clinical setting with 2-hour post-administration observation.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Ketamine can provide rapid relief from depression, often within 4 hours of a single low-dose intravenous (IV) administration. The effects can persist for weeks, though relapse is common without additional treatment

questions.text: What is the usual therapeutic plasma concentration of lithium for long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
For long-term maintenance treatment, the recommended therapeutic range for lithium is between 0.4 and 0.8 mEq/L, typically achieved with a daily dose of 900 to 1,200 mg.

LITHIUM

  • Routine laboratory tests should be performed before starting lithium:
    • Serum creatinine (or 24-hour urine creatinine if renal function is a concern)
    • Electrolytes
    • Thyroid function (TSH, T3, T4)
    • Complete blood count (CBC)
    • ECG (Electrocardiogram)
    • Pregnancy test for women of childbearing age
  • Maintenance Dosage:
    • Typically between 900 mg and 1,200 mg daily for a plasma concentration of 0.6 to 1 mEq/L
    • Higher doses (1,200 to 1,800 mg daily) yield a plasma concentration of 0.8 to 1.2 mEq/L
    • Maintenance can be given in either two or three divided doses (regular-release) or in a single dose (sustained-release).
  • Discontinuation:
    • Gradual tapering of lithium is recommended to minimize the risk of recurrence of mania and to detect early signs of recurrence.

Laboratory Monitoring:

  • Serum Lithium Levels:
    • Regular monitoring is essential.
    • Frequency: Every 2 to 6 months for stable patients, more frequently if there are dosage adjustments or concerns about toxicity or non-compliance.
    • When to Measure: Lithium levels should be measured 12 hours after the last dose (±30 minutes) when the patient is on steady-state dosing (usually after 5 days).
  • Factors Affecting Lithium Levels:
    • Dietary sodium intake, mood state, activity level, and body position can influence lithium measurements.
    • Lithium levels can also be falsely elevated if blood is collected in a tube with lithium-heparin anticoagulant or if the lithium ion-selective electrode is old.
  • Therapeutic Range for Mania:
    • Typically 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/L (achieved with 1,800 mg/day)
  • Therapeutic Range for Maintenance:
    • Typically 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/L (achieved with 900 to 1,200 mg/day)
  • Variability:
    • Some patients may need a lithium concentration above 1.2 mEq/L to achieve therapeutic effects, while others may have no signs of toxicity at concentrations above 1.2 mEq/L.
  • Discontinuation Advice:
    • Never stop or modify the lithium regimen without consulting the physician, even if feeling well or experiencing side effects.
  • Tapering Off Lithium:
    • If a patient does not respond to lithium after 2 weeks or if adverse effects are noticed, the medication should be tapered off gradually over 1 to 2 weeks, and other mood-stabilizing medications should be considered.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Therapeutic Range for Mania:

  • Typically 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/L (achieved with 1,800 mg/day)

Therapeutic Range for Maintenance:

  • Typically 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/L (achieved with 900 to 1,200 mg/day)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common adverse effect of lamotrigine?
questions.solution:
The most common and concerning adverse effect of lamotrigine is the development of a rash, which can sometimes be severe. Although many rashes are benign, there is a risk that they may indicate serious conditions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis.

LAMOTRIGINE:

  • Development & Indications:
    • Initially developed for epilepsy; approved for bipolar I disorder maintenance (2003).
    • Effective for depressive episodes in bipolar disorder, but not for acute bipolar depression or mania.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Common: Dizziness, ataxia, headache, blurred vision.
    • Serious: Rash (can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome). Discontinue if rash develops.
  • Drug Interactions:
    • Valproic acid increases lamotrigine levels; Carbamazepine and others decrease levels.
  • Precautions:
    • Children under 16 should not use lamotrigine.
    • Gradually taper off over 2 weeks unless a rash appears.
  • Special Formulations:
    • Available as orally disintegrating tablets for easier swallowing.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common and concerning adverse effect of lamotrigine is the development of a rash, which can sometimes be severe. Although many rashes are benign, there is a risk that they may indicate serious conditions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis.

questions.text: Which β-blocker is most likely to cross the blood-brain barrier and have central nervous system (CNS) effects?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is lipophilic (fat-soluble), which allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier and produce central nervous system effects. Drugs that are more lipophilic are more likely to have CNS effects, such as sedation or vivid nightmares.

Β-ADRENERGIC RECEPTOR ANTAGONISTS:

  • β-adrenergic receptors control many organ functions via the sympathetic nervous system. β-blockers (like propranolol, metoprolol, atenolol) are used in psychiatry.
  • Lipophilicity of β-blockers determines their ability to cross the blood-brain barrier: more lipophilic ones affect the CNS.
  • Common β-blockers:
    • Propranolol: Used for anxiety (performance anxiety, PTSD), tremors, akathisia.
    • Pindolol: Used for antidepressant augmentation.
    • Metoprolol/ Atenolol: Selective for β1-receptors, fewer pulmonary side effects.
  • Therapeutic Uses:
    • Anxiety disorders (e.g., social anxiety, panic disorder).
    • Lithium-induced tremor.
    • Neuroleptic-induced akathisia.
    • Aggression, alcohol withdrawal, and antidepressant augmentation.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Common: Hypotension, bradycardia.
    • Contraindicated in asthma, diabetes, CHF, significant vascular disease.
    • Other effects: Sexual dysfunction, fatigue, vivid dreams, and in rare cases, depression or psychosis.
  • Drug Interactions: Increased plasma concentrations with certain drugs (e.g., antipsychotics), and possible hypertensive crisis with MAOIs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Propranolol is lipophilic (fat-soluble), which allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier and produce central nervous system effects. Drugs that are more lipophilic are more likely to have CNS effects, such as sedation or vivid nightmares.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the use of zolpidem, zaleplon, or eszopiclone?
questions.solution:
Zolpidem, zaleplon, and eszopiclone are mainly indicated for insomnia, not for alcohol withdrawal. They may be used off-label for certain other conditions like Parkinson's disease (zolpidem) or jet lag, but alcohol withdrawal is not a typical indication.

NONBENZODIAZEPINE GABA AGONISTS:

  • "Z Drugs": Zolpidem, zaleplon, and eszopiclone are nonbenzodiazepine GABA agonists used to treat insomnia.
  • Mechanism: These drugs bind to specific subunits of the GABA-A receptor, providing sedative effects with fewer muscle relaxant and anticonvulsant effects.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Rapid absorption; zaleplon has the shortest half-life (1 hour), while zolpidem and eszopiclone have longer half-lives (2.6 hrs and 6 hrs).
  • Indications: Primarily for insomnia, with occasional use in Parkinson's disease (zolpidem).
  • Adverse Effects: Headache, dizziness, amnesia, and rare hallucinations. Caution in elderly and breastfeeding women.
  • Drug Interactions: Caution with CNS depressants (alcohol, opioids) and enzyme inhibitors (e.g., cimetidine, fluvoxamine).

MELATONIN AGONISTS:

  • Ramelteon: FDA-approved for sleep-onset insomnia. It mimics melatonin, binding to MT1 and MT2 receptors in the brain.
  • Melatonin: Available over-the-counter, used for sleep disorders but not FDA-approved for insomnia treatment.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Ramelteon has a short half-life (1-2.6 hrs). Melatonin is quickly metabolized with a very short half-life (minutes).
  • Indications: Used for insomnia, circadian rhythm disorders, jet lag, and shift work sleep disorder.
  • Adverse Effects: Headache, somnolence, dizziness, and possible hormonal effects (prolactin increase).
  • Drug Interactions: Avoid with CYP1A2 inhibitors (e.g., fluvoxamine) and CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., ketoconazole).
  • Dosage: Ramelteon is typically dosed at 8 mg before bed. Melatonin is available in various forms but should not be taken with high-fat meals.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Zolpidem, zaleplon, and eszopiclone are mainly indicated for insomnia, not for alcohol withdrawal. They may be used off-label for certain other conditions like Parkinson's disease (zolpidem) or jet lag, but alcohol withdrawal is not a typical indication

choices.text: To prevent abuse by IV injection

questions.text: What is the reason why buprenorphine is combined with naloxone in medications like Suboxone?
questions.solution:
OST:

Methadone Use:

  • For detoxification and maintenance of opioid-dependent individuals.
  • Reduces risk of death, illicit drug use, criminal activity, and infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis).
  • Used in pregnant women to reduce risks to fetal and neonatal health.
  • Requires lifelong treatment for many patients.

Buprenorphine:

  • Partial opioid agonist, used for opioid maintenance therapy.
  • Less likely to cause lethal overdose compared to full agonists.
  • Available as Suboxone (buprenorphine + naloxone) to prevent misuse by injection.
  • Requires clinical supervision and dosage adjustments.

Tramadol:

  • Used for chronic pain and has antidepressant-like effects.
  • Complex pharmacology affecting multiple neurotransmitters.
  • Can cause withdrawal or dependence but is less addictive than other opioids.

Pregnancy Considerations:

  • Methadone maintenance improves obstetric and neonatal outcomes in pregnant women with opioid addiction.
  • Buprenorphine is preferred for pregnant women when used appropriately.

Pharmacokinetics:

  • Naltrexone and nalmefene block opioid effects but can cause nausea due to their action on µ-receptors.
  • Naloxone challenge test is used to confirm opioid-free state before starting treatment.

Option A: To prevent abuse by IV injection

Naloxone is added to buprenorphine in Suboxone to deter intravenous abuse. If injected, naloxone precipitates withdrawal symptoms, discouraging misuse.

Option B: To enhance the analgesic effects

Naloxone does not enhance the analgesic effects of buprenorphine; it is included to prevent abuse, not to increase pain relief.

Option C: To decrease the withdrawal symptoms

Naloxone does not help with withdrawal symptoms; buprenorphine alone manages withdrawal, while naloxone prevents misuse.

Option D: To prevent the ceiling effect

The ceiling effect is an inherent property of buprenorphine, not affected by naloxone, which does not alter the dose-response relationship.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases the blood concentration of acamprosate when co-administered?
questions.solution:
ACAMPROSATE:

  • Mechanism: Thought to antagonize glutamate overactivity and NMDA receptors, aiding in alcohol abstinence.
  • Indication: For maintaining abstinence in alcohol-dependent individuals who are already sober.
  • Adverse Effects: Headache, diarrhea, flatulence, mild and transient side effects.
  • Contraindications: Severe renal impairment.
  • Drug Interactions: No significant pharmacokinetic interactions with alcohol, disulfiram, or diazepam.
  • Dosage: 666 mg three times a day; adjust for renal impairment.
  • Precautions: Not for alcohol withdrawal; part of a comprehensive treatment plan.

Option A: Coadministration of naltrexone with acamprosate increases acamprosate's concentration in the blood, though no dosage adjustment is needed.

Option B: Diazepam does not significantly interact with acamprosate.

Option C: Disulfiram does not have an effect on acamprosate pharmacokinetics.

Option D: Alcohol and acamprosate do not affect each other's pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: What is the main pharmacological action of memantine in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
CHOLINESTERASE INHIBITORS

  • Drugs: Donepezil, Rivastigmine, Galantamine, Tacrine (no longer used).
  • Action: Inhibit cholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine in the brain to improve memory and cognition in Alzheimer's.
  • Indications: Mild to moderate Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Lewy body dementia, and traumatic brain injury.
  • Memantine: NMDA receptor antagonist for moderate to severe Alzheimer's; used with cholinesterase inhibitors.

Side Effects:

  • Donepezil: Nausea, diarrhea, weight loss, bradyarrhythmias.
  • Rivastigmine: Nausea, vomiting, dizziness, somnolence.
  • Galantamine: Dizziness, nausea, vomiting.
  • Tacrine: Hepatotoxicity (ALT/AST increase), nausea, myalgia.

MEMANTINE:

  • Action: Blocks NMDA receptors to prevent glutamate-induced toxicity.
  • Indication: Approved for moderate to severe Alzheimer's.
  • Side Effects: Dizziness, headache, constipation, confusion.

Option A: Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase:

This action is characteristic of cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine, not memantine. These drugs increase acetylcholine levels in the brain, but memantine works differently by blocking NMDA receptors.

Option B: Blockade of NMDA receptors:

Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist. It helps prevent the overstimulation of these receptors by glutamate, which can lead to neuronal damage in Alzheimer's disease. By blocking NMDA receptors, memantine protects neurons from excitotoxicity caused by excessive calcium influx.

Option C: Inhibition of butyrylcholinesterase:

Butyrylcholinesterase inhibitors are not the primary action of memantine. This action is seen in other cholinesterase inhibitors like rivastigmine, which target both acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase to improve cholinergic transmission.

Option D: Enhancement of acetylcholine release:

While acetylcholine release is enhanced by cholinesterase inhibitors, memantine does not work by this mechanism. It functions by modulating glutamatergic transmission rather than directly increasing acetylcholine levels.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist. It helps prevent the overstimulation of these receptors by glutamate, which can lead to neuronal damage in Alzheimer's disease. By blocking NMDA receptors, memantine protects neurons from excitotoxicity caused by excessive calcium influx.

choices.text: To create a life worth living for patients with BPD
To eliminate the need for pharmacotherapy
To focus on only the cognitive aspects of therapy

questions.text: What is the primary goal of Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)?
questions.solution:
The primary goal of DBT is to help patients with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) create a meaningful life despite their struggles with emotional regulation and self-destructive behaviours.

DBT: DIALECTICAL BEHAVIOUR THERAPY

  • DBT is effective for treating Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) and other disorders.
  • Key goals: create a life worth living, reduce self-destructive behaviours.
  • Four treatment modes: group skills training, individual therapy, phone consultations, consultation team.
  • Focus on enhancing skills, motivation, and generalization of behaviour.
  • DBT shows positive outcomes, including reduced parasuicidal behaviours and improved social/work performance.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The primary goal of DBT is to help patients with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) create a meaningful life despite their struggles with emotional regulation and self-destructive behaviors.

questions.text: Which of the following is a behavioural technique used in CBT?
questions.solution:
Option A: Recognizing automatic thoughts

This is a cognitive technique, not a behavioural one. It involves identifying negative or distorted thoughts that influence emotions and behaviour.

Option B: Mindfulness meditation

While mindfulness can be combined with CBT, it is not a behavioural technique. It is a practice derived from Buddhist traditions aimed at increasing awareness and focus on the present moment.

Option C: Activity scheduling

This is a behavioural technique used in CBT to encourage patients to plan and engage in activities that promote positive emotions and behaviours, helping to reduce depression and anxiety.

Option D: Teaching problem-solving skills

This is a cognitive technique, not a behavioural one. It helps individuals learn effective ways to address and solve life challenges, reducing stress and negative thinking.

COGNITIVE BEHAVIOUR THERAPY (CBT)

  • Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT) is a psychotherapy aimed at correcting maladaptive thinking patterns, offering relief from related symptoms.
  • Developed by Beck and Meichenbaum.
  • Used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, panic disorders, phobias, eating disorders, anticipatory anxiety, and sometimes psychotic symptoms like delusions and hallucinations.
  • A typical CBT schedule involves 15 sessions over 3 months.
  • It involves:
  • Cognitive techniques:
    • Recognizing and correcting negative automatic thoughts
    • Teaching reattribution techniques
    • Increasing objectivity and testing maladaptive assumptions
    • Decentering
  • Behavioural techniques:
    • Activity scheduling
    • Homework assignments
    • Graded task assignment
    • Behavioural rehearsal
    • Role-playing
    • Diversion techniques
  • Problem-solving skills:
    • Teaching effective methods to manage life challenges
  • Mindfulness:
    • Originally Buddhist, mindfulness techniques are sometimes combined with CBT.

choices.text: Voluntary control of the autonomic nervous system through operant conditioning

questions.text: What is the primary principle behind biofeedback?
questions.solution:
BIOFEEDBACK:

  • Biofeedback involves using real-time physiological feedback to help patients control autonomic nervous system functions (e.g., heart rate, muscle tension).
  • It is based on operant conditioning and helps in self-regulation of bodily functions.
  • Techniques used include EMG, EEG, GSR, and thermistors for measuring muscle tension, brain waves, skin conductivity, and temperature.
  • Applications: Used for treating conditions like migraines, hypertension, anxiety, bruxism, insomnia, and stress.
  • Relaxation methods like progressive muscle relaxation and autogenic training are often combined with biofeedback.
  • Progressive Relaxation involves tense-and-relax muscle exercises, while Autogenic Training uses self-suggestion to induce relaxation.
  • Applied Relaxation involves using relaxation techniques in stressful situations.
  • Biofeedback is a key tool in behavioral medicine, teaching patients to change harmful behaviors and manage stress-related conditions.

Option A: Relaxation through physical exercises

Biofeedback may involve relaxation techniques, but its primary principle is not about physical exercises. It focuses on using real-time feedback to control autonomic functions.

Option B: Voluntary control of the autonomic nervous system through operant conditioning

Biofeedback works on the principle that individuals can learn to control involuntary bodily functions, such as heart rate or muscle tension, by receiving real-time feedback and using operant conditioning.

Option C: Focused meditation techniques

While mindfulness and meditation can be combined with biofeedback, biofeedback itself is not centered around meditation but on using physiological feedback to promote self-regulation.

Option D: Immediate intervention in psychotic disorders

Biofeedback is not used as an immediate intervention for psychotic disorders. It focuses on regulating physiological processes to treat conditions like anxiety or pain rather than psychosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Biofeedback involves using real-time physiological feedback to help patients control autonomic nervous system functions (e.g., heart rate, muscle tension).

It is based on operant conditioning and helps in self-regulation of bodily functions.

choices.text: When a faster response is required
For patients with high risk of seizure

questions.text: In which situation is unilateral ECT generally preferred over bilateral ECT?
questions.solution:
ELECTROCONVULSIVE THERAPY

Indications:

  • Major severe depression (with suicidal risk, stupor, etc.).
  • Severe catatonia, psychosis (schizophrenia or mania) with risks.
  • ECT can also be used in organic mental disorders, medical conditions like neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Contraindications:

  • Absolute: Raised intracranial pressure.
  • Relative: Recent MI, hypertension, CVA, pulmonary disease.

Technique:

  • Modified ECT with anesthesia and muscle relaxants is commonly used.
  • Electrodes placed bilaterally or unilaterally depending on the situation.

Seizure Duration:

  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting 25-30 seconds is ideal.

Side Effects:

  • Memory disturbances, confusion, headaches, cardiovascular issues.
  • Mortality rate is low (1:10,000 treatments).

Mechanism:

  • ECT likely affects catecholamine pathways and mood-regulating brain regions.

Duration of Therapy:

  • Usually 6-10 treatments, spaced out (max 3 per week)

Option A: In cases of severe psychosis

Bilateral ECT is generally preferred in cases of severe psychosis (e.g., schizophrenia or manic episodes) due to its higher efficacy. Unilateral ECT is typically not used as the first choice for severe psychosis.

Option B: When a faster response is required

Bilateral ECT typically provides a faster and more robust therapeutic response than unilateral ECT. Unilateral ECT is less effective and often requires more sessions to achieve the same outcome.

Option C: To reduce memory impairment

Unilateral ECT, especially when placed on the non-dominant hemisphere (usually the right side in right-handed individuals), is associated with fewer cognitive side effects, particularly memory impairment, compared to bilateral ECT.

Option D: For patients with high risk of seizure

The risk of seizure is controlled by proper medication and technique, and unilateral ECT is not specifically chosen to reduce seizure risk. It's primarily used to minimize cognitive side effects rather than seizure risks.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Unilateral ECT generally preferred over bilateral ECT to reduce memory impairment

questions.text: Which area of the brain is often targeted in Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation to treat affective disorders?
questions.solution:
TRANSCRANIAL MAGNETIC STIMULATION

  • Definition of TMS:
    • TMS (Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation) uses rapidly changing magnetic fields to induce electric currents in the brain, stimulating neurons without electrodes.
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • TMS causes neuronal depolarization, leading to action potentials. Repetitive TMS (rTMS) can induce lasting effects via neuroplasticity and synaptic changes.
  • Therapeutic Use:
    • TMS is used for treating psychiatric disorders like depression by targeting the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) to normalize its activity. Low-frequency rTMS inhibits right DLPFC; high-frequency rTMS stimulates left DLPFC.
  • Acute and Prolonged Effects:
    • Acute: Motor responses, temporary disruptions in perception.
    • Prolonged: Changes in synaptic efficacy, neurotrophic factors, and cortical excitability.
  • Side Effects & Risks:
    • Risks include seizures, especially with rTMS and high doses.
    • Single-pulse TMS is low-risk for most people, while rTMS requires careful screening.
  • Patient Selection:
    • TMS is considered for patients who haven't responded to antidepressants or experienced side effects from them. It's less effective than ECT for severe cases.
  • Future Directions:
    • Research is focused on improving TMS effectiveness, identifying responsive patients, exploring deeper brain stimulation, and optimizing pulse shapes for better results.

Option A: Primary visual cortex

The primary visual cortex (V1) is responsible for processing visual information, not typically involved in affective disorders like depression, which is why it’s not the target area for TMS in such conditions.

Option B: Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC)

The DLPFC is often targeted in TMS for treating affective disorders, as reduced activity in this area has been associated with conditions like depression. TMS is used to increase excitability and normalize function in this region.

Option C: Hippocampus

The hippocampus is primarily involved in memory and emotional processing. While it may play a role in mood regulation, it's not the main target for TMS in the treatment of affective disorders.

Option D: Basal ganglia

The basal ganglia are involved in movement and reward processing. While they may be implicated in mood regulation, they are not the primary focus in TMS for affective disorders compared to areas like the DLPFC

choices.text: Children and adults, including deaf and mute populations

questions.text: Which population is the Seguin Form Board Test suitable for?
questions.solution:
TYPES OF INTELLIGENCE TESTS:

Seguin Form Board Test (SFB): Measures psychomotor abilities, hand-eye coordination, and cognitive functioning. Suitable for children, adults, and deaf/mute populations.

Advanced Progressive Matrices: Consists of 48 items, divided into two sets (Set I: 12, Set II: 36), suitable for individuals with above-average intelligence.

Vineland Social Maturity Scale (VSMS): Measures social intelligence and development across 8 domains (e.g., self-help, communication, socialization). Calculated using the formula: SQ/CA * 100.

Binet Kamath's Test of Intelligence (BKT): Indian adaptation of the Stanford-Binet Test, covering 6 subtests for ages 3-22, measuring language, memory, reasoning, and more.

Wechsler Intelligence Scales: Developed by Dr. David Wechsler, includes multiple scales for different age groups:

  • WPPSI: 2 years 6 months to 7 years 7 months
  • WISC: 7 years to 15 years 11 months
  • WAIS: 16 years and older

Option A: Only children

This is incorrect because the Seguin Form Board Test is suitable for both children and adults, not just children. It is designed to assess cognitive and psychomotor abilities across age groups.

Option B: Adults with visual impairments

This is incorrect because the test is not specifically designed for individuals with visual impairments, though it can be administered to a wide range of people. It focuses on general cognitive and motor skills rather than being targeted for a specific disability like visual impairments.

Option C: Children and adults, including deaf and mute populations
The Seguin Form Board Test is versatile and can be used with individuals across various age groups, including those who are deaf and mute, as it relies on visual and motor coordination rather than language.

Option D: Only individuals with intellectual disabilities

While it can be used for people with intellectual disabilities, the test is not exclusive to them and is appropriate for a broad range of individuals, including those with typical cognitive functioning.

questions.text: Which projective test is known for being particularly useful for assessing both emotional and intellectual states?
questions.solution:
The Rorschach test is valuable for assessing emotional and intellectual states as well as uncovering hidden personality traits.

Option A: Wechsler Intelligence Scale:

This is an intelligence test measuring cognitive abilities, not specifically designed to assess emotional or intellectual states.

Option B: Rorschach Inkblot Test:

A projective test used to assess both emotional and intellectual states, revealing hidden personality traits through responses to ambiguous inkblots.

Option C: Seguin Form Board Test:

A performance-based test that measures psychomotor abilities and cognitive functioning, but not emotional states.

Option D: Thematic Apperception Test:

A projective test assessing underlying motives and emotions through storytelling, but not directly measuring intellectual states.

PERSONALITY TESTS:

Types of Personality Tests:

  • Paper-Pencil Tests: Self-report inventories like MMPI and MCMI, where answers are based on true/false responses.
  • Projective Tests: Tests like Rorschach and TAT designed to assess hidden emotions and internal conflicts via ambiguous stimuli.

MMPI (Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory):

  • Developed in 1937 and revised in 1989 as MMPI-2.
  • Contains 567 items with true/false responses, takes 60-90 minutes.
  • Used for assessing personality and psychological conditions.

Projective Tests:

  • Rorschach Inkblot Test:
    • Developed in 1921 by Hermann Rorschach.
    • Consists of 10 symmetrical inkblot plates.
    • Objective, culture-free test for assessing emotional and intellectual states, personality traits, and psychodiagnosis.


  • Thematic Apperception Test (TAT):
    • Developed in the 1930s by Henry A. Murray and Christiana Morgan.
    • Uses ambiguous pictures to assess underlying motives, emotions, and personal concerns.
    • Indian adaptation by Uma Chaudhary in 1960.

  • Children's Apperception Test (CAT):
    • Developed in 1949 by Leopold and Sonya Bellack.
    • Uses animal and human-themed images to assess personality and psychological health of children (ages 5-13).
    • CAT-A uses animals; CAT-H uses human figures.
    • Assesses personality, maturity, and conflict resolution through thematic storytelling.

Purpose and Interpretation of Apperception Tests:

  • Assess personality, level of maturity, psychological health, reality testing, drives, defenses, and autonomy.
  • Focus on identifying the central character, the needs of the character, environmental influences (presses), and the outcome of the story.
